abstract.p: Letter from J C Jordan says billions of dollars lost as result of air traffic gridlock could have been used to finance high-speed rail from city center to city center

block.p: Doesn't it seem, from your Sept. 5 front-page article about air traffic gridlock, that the billions in dollars lost, wasted or thrown around ($5 billion lost last year alone, and $40 billion to be spent through 2004 with no end in sight), that some of that money would go a long way to finance high-speed rail?

Doesn't it seem, from your Sept. 5 front-page article about air traffic gridlock, that the billions in dollars lost, wasted or thrown around ($5 billion lost last year alone, and $40 billion to be spent through 2004 with no end in sight), that some of that money would go a long way to finance high-speed rail?

From city center to city center for trips out to about 600 miles, rail is faster and with a much larger carrying capacity than comparable short-haul airline service. Not only is it faster and more comfortable, but also the reduction in load on the now overstrained airports would go a long way toward freeing up capacity for those longer trips that are more feasible by air.
J. C. JORDAN San Francisco, Sept. 5, 2000
